speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument this morning in Case 13-1433, Brumfield v. Cain. Mr. DeSanctis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I'm sorry, but isn't -- I -- I don't -- whether I agree with you or not, isn't it your burden to prove that he had some deficits in adaptive ability?  You have to make the threshold showing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what did you show that met that prong in any way?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, how is it --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How is that Alderson Reporting Company determination under State law pertinent to the question here?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I understand that.  But given -- given the facts that were presented -- and this is what the language of the law is, of course.  The evidence presented in the State court proceeding, how is that pertinent on the Federal -- Federal question?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In other words, I don't think it would be a different -- your burden, I don't think, would be different on the question that's presented here if the State law required a higher threshold or -- or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But in your answer to Justice Sotomayor, I -- I thought you said, well, if the State has a very low standard.  What difference does that make?  Are you saying that if the State with its Alderson Reporting Company regular processes takes a Federal rule and misinterprets the rule as part of its process, then there's a Federal violation? Is that your point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, what -- what difference does it make -- and I think this was what the Chief Justice was concerned with as well. What difference does it make that Louisiana has a low bar or a high bar?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And then while -- while you're on -- on this: Suppose at the trial, in the sentencing phase, an expert -- medical expert testified, in my view, this defendant does not have an intellectual disability as we define that in medical terms. Would you be here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's a hypothetical of Alderson Reporting Company course.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, the first question -- the first question presented in your petition is "Whether a State court that considers the evidence presented at a petitioner's penalty phase proceeding as determinative of the petitioner's claim of intellectual disability under Atkins... has based its decision on an unreasonable determination of the facts." So suppose that at the penalty phase proceeding there is evidence of 5 IQ tests, all above 140.  Would it be wrong to say that that's determinative?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So the answer to the first question is no, it is not necessarily unconstitutional to regard the penalty phase evidence as determinative.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is -- is your point --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is your point that we are involved in a wholly different inquiry once Atkins is on the books?  Because when you were before the State court at the sentencing hearing, you weren't talking about intellectual disability.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You were talking about some mitigating factors.  So the State court never had before it an Atkins claim.  An Atkins claim is raised for the first time on post-conviction review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you not think it would have been ineffective assistance of counsel pre-Atkins for a lawyer who had a client who was severely mentally disabled not to bring that fact forward in the -- in the sentencing hearing for consideration by the jury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even -- even though it wasn't, you know, a mandatory Federal basis for -- for exempting him from the death penalty, surely you would want the jury to consider that kind of evidence, wouldn't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I don't find that persuasive.  It seems to me you -- you have the burden to show that there was some basis for the State Supreme Court coming out the other way, and that basis should have been in the record, according to the Federal statute, and your only defense is, well, we didn't put anything in the record because Atkins had not yet been decided.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Fine.   So let's get rid of that argument that Atkins had not been decided. That -- that had nothing to do with the case, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Am I wrong in my understanding that the record included an expert report stating that Brumfield possessed, quote, "a normal capacity to learn and acquire information" and that he had, quote, "adequate problem and" -- "and reasoning skill" -- "problem-solving and reasoning skills."  Is -- is -- is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It -- it was not in the record?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if it was in it, it's pretty categorical, you know.  I would think that's enough for the State court to hang its hat on.  I don't think we -- we can possibly find that it was unreasonable evidentiary finding, if -- if that was indeed in the record.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did -- did the State put it in the record?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And you didn't, but another -- another expert referred to it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the State wasn't -- didn't put it in evidence, so it wasn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and are we talking Alderson Reporting Company about the trial record now?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: At the sentencing -- at the sentencing hearing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did you ask --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did you ask the State court for funds as a matter of Federal right?  The other side says, did you ask for funds for State habeas only under State law and not under Federal law; is that true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. DeSanctis, I -- I will perhaps talk about what is a little confusing; if not confusing, disconcerting in this case.  There seems to be an inequity that one could perceive that says you can use the penalty phase record, but the other side can't to challenge your conclusions.  Because that's basically what you're saying.  And so and that was, I think, Justice Alito's point, which is you concede on some -- in some circumstances the State might. What makes your case different?        Now, I do know that this -- in this case you're saying you provided some -- a sufficient amount of some evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And the State was unreasonable by not giving you a hearing to determine the merits of your claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  We don't even get to the issue of whether you were entitled to funds at that hearing, but I don't even think under Louisiana you wouldn't be, once you've made the threshold showing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  So answer my question, because it's -- it's a bit of a takeoff from Justice Alito's question, which is what is -- why in your case can't the State rely on the evidence in the penalty phase, if that's what you're relying on to make your sum showing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The court always has to do it itself, even when there are experts.  I mean, I don't understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Put this -- put this in perspective for a moment.  Suppose we're in the district court on a petition for habeas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Federal -- United States district court, and the question is:  Is the defendant entitled to a hearing?  This petitioner entitled to a hearing? what is the standard that the district court must find -- met before the district court has a hearing on the facts?  Before the district court can have its experts.  Does he have to find that the State collateral decision was clearly erroneous?  Or that there was a prima facie evidence of -- of disability that the State collateral court ignored?  What's the district court have to do before it decides it's going to have a hearing and call its own experts? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What standard must it meet and did it meet that standard here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So are you saying --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- that the district court, the United States district court decided to have a hearing because it found that the State court's Alderson Reporting Company collateral review determination was, fill in the blank, clearly erroneous?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's the AEDPA standard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Unreasonable because there were some open questions, or because no one could read the record to say that there was evidence that he had no disability?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Also, we've heard -- heard a lot of discussion on the evidence at issue in this particular case.  What -- what is the broader significance of that discussion here?  I'm concerned your answer to Justice Alito was that the answer to your -- your first question was no, it's not necessarily the case that it's unreasonable determination in a situation where the State considers the evidence blah Alderson Reporting Company blah.  But you're saying now that in this case it was?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So what is the broader significance of the question you want us to decide?  Since you've conceded that the question -- the answer to the first question presented is no.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right, right.  But I mean --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.  But you -- your question is:  If it's determinative, is it unreasonable?  And Justice Alito --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- gave you an example of where it was determinative and you said it was not unreasonable.  So as a general rule, the question is -- the answer to the question is no.  And in terms of what we're going to decide, I just need to know whether it is simply whether the facts in your Alderson Reporting Company particular case lead to a particular result, or if there is some more general legal rule that you're arguing for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can you go back to Justice Kennedy's question? And -- and either working it backwards or working it forward, but you're not taking it step by step, okay? Atkins I believe says that a State doesn't have to give you a hearing if you haven't met a threshold.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And that's -- and that threshold definition is a reasonable --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Not Louisiana, Atkins. What did Atkins say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It doesn't, but it does articulate that there has to be a threshold and it has to be some doubt as to mental capacity, correct? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Some reason to believe. So that was the standard. Some reason to believe that an individual's mental capacity is -- is compromised, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So is your first argument that there was enough evidence to have -- for you to have been entitled to a hearing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why don't you tell us the three -- you said that in the State habeas, there were three things that were unreasonable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So tell us what they were.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There was a second.  Was there not testimony about a second IQ test that was a little bit higher?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: 75 I thought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There was one that was 75. Was there another one that was higher than 75?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought the former --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought the former was that the question you sought to bring before us; namely, that the State court couldn't use it at all, period.  I mean, question one that you -- you presented in your petition is as follows:  "Whether a State court that considers the evidence presented at a Petitioner's penalty phase proceeding as determinative of the Petitioner's claim of intellectual disability under Atkins has based its decision on an unreasonable determination of the facts."  Whether a State court, any State court, not this particular State court, but whether any State court that makes its decision based upon a pre-Atkins penalty phase hearing is automatically -- has automatically made an unreasonable determination of the facts.  Wasn't that the question you presented?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, fine.  That's what it sounds like.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought your case included the following:  Atkins says you cannot sentence Alderson Reporting Company to death and execute an intellectually disabled person. So Mr. Smith, whose case is not final, says to the judge, Judge, I would like to produce evidence I am intellectually disabled.  The State says, no, you can't. That would clearly violate Atkins.  Wouldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, suppose it says, yes, you can -- now, we don't have an Atkins.  A standard which says when you do and when you don't have to state, let this person present evidence.  We don't say it.  But the State has found one.  The State of Louisiana has a standard, and I take it if that's a good enough standard, that's what we should follow. And that standard from State v. Williams says, we will give you a hearing, if you, Mr. Smith, provide objective factors that will put at issue -- put at issue, the fact of mental retardation.  If you will come forward with some evidence to put your mental condition at issue.  And so I guess, unless we think Louisiana can't use that standard, that that standard is good enough for Federal purposes.  And, therefore, the issue is did your client and you put forward some evidence to put your mental condition at issue. And as long as you came forward with some evidence, then unless we're prepared to write some new Alderson Reporting Company Federal standard for when you have to give a hearing and when not, that's the question. And you're saying, among other things, of course, Judges -- you're telling us -- of course we put forward some evidence. In fact, we think we put forward a lot more, and we would have put forward a lot more if the hearing hadn't been pre-Atkins. Isn't that your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So let's get -- so let's get to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Thank you for putting it so clearly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I think that's important that that be your argument--

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- whether you say -- I mean, it's important if it really is your argument. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And it is, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I don't want to intrude too Alderson Reporting Company much on your rebuttal time, but as the case has been argued, I think you're making a strong argument that is purely a factual argument about this case, that you are not making an argument about the categorical -- categorical rule about not considering evidence at a pre-Atkins penalty phase proceeding. And unless you can point to precedent that shows that it was clearly established that you had a right to funding, then your -- your inability to put in evidence via the funding is not to be considered.  And all that is before us is whether, on the evidence that was in the record at the State -- at a post-conviction proceeding, it was an unreasonable application of Federal -- of constitutional law.  That's the question; right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All right.  An unreasonable determination of fact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But it's purely fact-bound.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There's no broader legal issue involved here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No cross-cutting legal issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: On -- in the whole case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Burns.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  But that's the standard.  That's what I think -- the quest -- of course you can't know whether it's unreasonable or not unreasonable unless you know what standard you're trying to meet.  And my impression is -- and that's why I went on at length, and you heard what I said -- and the -- and it's really to you; I want to be sure he adopts it -- the standards seem to be the standard you are entitled to a hearing, says Louisiana, indeed a new one, if you meet the standard of State v. Williams.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And that seemed to me good enough to be a Federal standard in the absence of any other. Now, am I right about that or wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Forget funding for the moment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.  I agree with that.  I just want to know factors to show what.  And am I right in saying in the absence in Atkins of any standard about when you have to have a hearing, that the State standard is good enough.  What he wants is a hearing.  He doesn't want us -- he'd like it -- but he doesn't want -- we don't have to say whether this person is intellectually disabled or not.  He wants a hearing.  And there is nothing in Atkins that says what the standard is to give him a hearing.  Therefore, I looked at the State standard from Williams and thought that's good enough to serve as a Federal standard.  Now, am I right or wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.  No.  You're not answering my question.  Of course we defer to the State, and we defer to the State when it makes what judgment? The judgment you, Mr. Defendant, are not entitled to a hearing.  So what's the standard under which they decide Alderson Reporting Company whether he's entitled to a hearing or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And I thought it's State v. Williams.  Am I right, or am I wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Excuse me.  Are we going around in a circle, a little bit of a circle?  It seems to me that if what happened here was the right thing, the Federal court went back and said, did the State properly preclude this Petitioner from putting on or discovering evidence?  Did it improperly fail to hold a hearing?  And the court there said, by the -- the courts -- by any standard, there was some evidence -- certainly by the State standard, but even by a constitutional standard, there was some evidence of incompetency.  He was entitled to a hearing.  They didn't give it to him, so now I will give him the hearing, because this is Federal habeas.  And, in fact, we have said if a State improperly precludes you from developing a claim, then there is no deference owed to the State. So what we're really looking at was, was the Federal hearing properly granted?  You did not argue Alderson Reporting Company that on the basis of the evidence produced at the Federal hearing, that this man was not intellectually disabled.  You have put all your eggs in the basket of, on the record that didn't permit a hearing, he didn't make out a threshold finding.  That's been your only defense so far.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So if we disagree with that -- if we disagree with that, what are you left with?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why?  Ah, to -- to view the conclusion from the facts developed there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that isn't -- that isn't -- at this moment, I'll put it once more, and see if I get an absolute, definite answer from you, and I'm overstating, but if I had to decide at this moment whether there is enough evidence for you to win on the point is he intellectually disabled, I would say you win.  If I decide -- have to decide whether or not he presented enough evidence to get a hearing, I would say you lose. Now, that's why it's important to me to know.  Are we trying to decide here whether there was enough evidence, such that the State under Federal law was unreasonable in not granting him a hearing, there I look at the standards of Williams, and I think you lose. If we're deciding something else, like whether he's intellectually disabled, and I'm repeating myself, I think you win. That's why I want your answer to the question of which are we deciding, or both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But Ms. Burns -- Ms. Burns, Alderson Reporting Company I think what Justice Breyer is driving at is just this, and reasonable people might disagree on the answer to this, but I think, you know, the determination that the State court was making at that moment was whether to have a hearing.  And under Louisiana law, I don't think you disagree with this, I don't think anybody could disagree with this, under Louisiana law, you have a hearing when the defendant has come forward, and it's -- the burden is on the defendant -- but when the defendant has come forward with some evident -- some evidence that raises a reasonable doubt as to his mental capacity. That's the standard that's in Williams, it's repeated again in Dunn.  You don't agree -- disagree with that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And -- and so what Justice Breyer is suggesting is that when we -- when we realize that that's the determination that the State court is making, whether the defendant has come forward with some evidence putting his mental capacity at issue, it looks awfully like an unreasonable determination of facts to say that this record does not meet that standard. That's all that the case is about, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I think what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the -- but adaptive -- adaptive was not relevant to the -- the determination at the sentencing hearing, because there was no Atkins.  They were trying to show mental deficit, but they adapted something when we're making an Atkins determination.  And there was -- that was never before the sentencing court.  It's only after Atkins is decided that adaptive becomes -- becomes relevant. But I didn't -- I wanted to ask you something in this record that's disturbing, and maybe you can explain it.  There is a brief -- you know it; it's by Justice Calogero -- that says there were 18 people who were sentenced to death and -- and before Atkins.  Then Atkins is decided.  Every one except for this Petitioner got a hearing in the State court; is that true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Please don't. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But Ms. Dunn, if we could go back, just on this point:  You said he didn't meet the standard.  And the standard is, as Justice Breyer suggested and you agreed, the one that comes from Dunn. And what I understand Mr. Brumfield to be saying is, look, all I need is some evidence.  The evidence that was in the trial record, even though it was pre-Atkins, the evidence was -- that was in the trial record was, I Alderson Reporting Company had a very low IQ, 75.  In addition, there was some evidence of -- of adaptive deficits, even -- even though they weren't trying to prove this point, evidence came in that he didn't read very well, he didn't write very well, he had problems processing information.  So that there was all that evidence. And then you sort of top -- when you look at the -- what the court said, I mean, basically, each one of the three things that the court said was just wrong. You know, the 75 is evidence of disability, there was evidence of adaptive functioning, and this idea that the court had that evidence relating to an antisocial personality somehow precluded the finding of mental disability is wrong as well. So I guess the question that Justice Breyer's question really leads to is like:  What's not some evidence here?  And didn't the court just misunderstand what -- what record it was looking at and what it was doing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that's the point.  It seems to me -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the point you have to attack.  Does the State saying that there has to be some evidence, does that mean if there is one item of evidence -- even though it's outweighed by everything else, it's contradicted by other -- by other witnesses -- if there's one little peppercorn of evidence, you have to go on to a hearing?  Is that what the State rule means?  Or does it mean when you consider the entirety, including the rebuttal evidence -- - --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- is there reasonably some evidence of his mental disability?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought that's what it was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Oh, sure, I consider the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Then -- then --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But wait a minute. Wait a minute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But wait a minute. Then there is a legal question here. And the legal question is: Can a State make the final determination of -- of mental incapacity, or lack thereof, based on a trial record that did not address the issue? That was the question presented. And you're saying it can, and what your adversary is saying, if there is some evidence of mental incapacity, then I'm entitled to a separate hearing that addresses that question alone; I can put in additional evidence and contradict whatever happened at the penalty stage. That's what his point is. Why is he wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You don't disagree that in Williams and Dunn, your own supreme court said, it's a double-edged sword, and we don't expect counsel to raise an issue that doesn't get them off.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We're all on the same page.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no.  I think we're all on the same page here, and I think we've made some progress in this, because I agree with you, and I agree with Justice Scalia that what we have to do –and there isn’t to - is to look at the whole record and see, keeping in mind the fact that it was a pre-Atkins record, and they didn't know about Atkins, but looking at the whole record, is the Louisiana court clearly wrong?  Is it unreasonable in saying there wasn't enough evidence, even though there has to be some, which is up to them pretty much how they say the some, but they're unreasonable in saying that there wasn't some evidence justifying a hearing.  And the only way to do that is for us to read it.  Is -- is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Would you agree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I agree with that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I haven't read the whole record, you know, and I doubt that I'm going to.  And -- and I doubt that this Court is going to read the whole record in all of these Atkins cases in the future.  I mean, what -- what you're saying is -- is -- you don't think it's -- it's fantastical?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.  No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Not every one.  They want to do this one, and I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The Petitioner -- the Petitioner's counsel conceded that if in this hearing, at the sentencing hearing, medical evidence was that in the opinion of the expert witness, this defendant, it -- has no intellectual disability, this would be a Alderson Reporting Company different case.  That's not in this case.  And what is in this case -- and you have still not answered Justice Breyer's question echoed by Justice Kagan.  Don't we look at Dunn and Williams to see what the standard is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And you have not said yes, and you have not said no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But he had no money to do it.  He said, if I had money I would investigate and I would come up with a lot more than I did at the sentencing hearing, but the State won't give me any money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What addition --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What was there in addition that was put in? He did get funding when he was in Federal court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm not talking about the sentencing hearing. I'm talking about the Federal habeas. What -- what, was there additional evidence?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Didn't counsel --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In the State --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In the State court, did Petitioner say, give me a hearing, and if you do, I will produce additional evidence without having funding?  Or did he say, give me a hearing and if you -- and provide me with funding so that I can put in additional evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I see a -- unless we know the answer to that question, I don't know how we can answer the question of whether there should have been a hearing.  If he wasn't going to produce anything more at the hearing, then what was already in the record, there would be no point in granting a hearing. And so if the only purpose of the hearing was to allow him to put in additional evidence with funding, case comes down to the question whether it was unconstitutional -- whether under AEDPA it was clearly established that it was unconstitutional for the State court to deny funding for this purpose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Because, Ms. Burns, wouldn't it be right to think, sure, he'd rather have had funding, but he wanted the hearing regardless of whether he was going to get funding.  And he can go out and seek pro bono support.  He could try to go back to the same experts that he had used at the sentencing. So even without funding, the opportunity for a hearing might have been worth something to him.  And what's clear, isn't it,  this is the -- you said that there is questions as to whether he asked for funding or didn't ask for funding.  What's clear is that he asked for a hearing, isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, often in -- often, in order to obtain, a hearing a party whom is moving for a Alderson Reporting Company hearing has to make a proffer of what will be shown at the hearing.  It makes no sense to say we're going to have a hearing and I want a hearing and I have the burden of proving at the hearing that I'm entitled to something, but I don't have any evidence to prove the -- the point that I need to prove.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So it does seem to come down to funding, unless there is something in the -- in the record, and maybe you or your counsel can point to something in the record that shows that he wanted a hearing, even if he wasn't going to have funding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're saying he doesn't want funding.  He didn't want funding, you're saying, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say he proceeded Alderson Reporting Company without it, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So he didn't want funding. Ms. BURNS:        He --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't help your case.  It hurts your case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, in looking at the record, what are we supposed to do with Dr. Jordan's report?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, that's a bit of a copout.  You're the prosecutor.  Was it admitted at trial -- at the sentencing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: At the sentencing hearing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But it was not before the State court?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There was -- it was discussed during -- I gather, during cross-examination several times.  What is the status of documents that are the subject of cross-examination under Louisiana law? Are they part of the record?  Are they simply extraneous material that can be consulted?  What -- what are they?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The report had been tendered what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm waiting for the last half of your sentence.  If -- right? -- if a witness testified about it and if it was tendered to the court, then what is the conclusion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it becomes part of the record?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We were told that the three reasons given by the State habeas court, that all of those, the three, were wrong.  That's what the counsel for the Petitioner told us. And what is your -- your response to that? 75, we know that it isn't an absolute, that you can have a 75 score and still be intellectually disabled.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  Could I go back to your answer to Justice Scalia? It -- I've practiced elsewhere, and if anything's made a part of the record, you give it an evidence number.  Louisiana is different; it's not -- it's not introduced into evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: As the answer -- but how do we know the trial judge read it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can we go back to -- Alderson Reporting Company you're answering my question, and then -- and you told me the 75 IQ, but there were two others.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was nothing on adaptive behavior, but in fact, there was evidence -- some evidence of adaptive behavior.  And then the third point, antisocial behavior, there's nothing inconsistent about being antisocial and having an intellectual disability.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the finding is perfectly consistent with -- with intellectual disability.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Because Atkins wasn't decided?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. DeSanctis, you have two minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
